Posted: June 9, 2015
												Bioshock:Positives:+ There is a really engaging story in Bioshock with a twist that you won't expect. Audio logs which supplement the plotline can be found by exploring the environment and are a welcome addition. The game is set in the underwater city of Rapture and follows two men who struggle for power - Andrew Ryan, leader of the famous Ryan Industries and Frank Fontaine.+ There are quite a few weapons that can be upgraded, like crossbows, shotguns, pistols, the Tommy Gun, grenade launchers and a chemical thrower which fires liquid nitrogen, napalm and electric gel.+ A key part of Bioshock is the use of Plasmids, genetic abilities which can freeze enemies solid, incinerate or electrocute them. Unleash a swarm of killer insects or create a decoy target to draw fire away from you. There's many options here.+ To add greater complexity there are tonics which improve your skills in countless ways. Physical tonics add healing benefits and eve restoration (eve is required to cast plasmids), engineering tonics are crucial to hacking safes, door combinations, gun turrets, vending machines and cameras. Then you've got combat tonics for physical damage resistance.  + The characters are interesting, the shooting is great, basically it's fun which is the most important pro.Mixed:~ Only about 15 hours of content for this FPS, which is not much (played on medium difficulty and didn't really have any issues). It's not the worst I've seen but clearly it's lacking in gameplay longevity. ~ Graphics are not bad considering the age of this game. Average.~ Somewhat linear game. It is not open-world and there are no side missions, it's strictly one area to the next. With that said, it's forgiveable since the developers have put some sort of effort into hidden areas and locations which aren't essential.Negatives:- Very poor map design, confusing to navigate and find out where to go for your next objective. Overall Score: 8/10Very much recommended!

												This game, to me, is the embodiment of a horror-action-shooter. It is a great game with many different ways to play and explore. I really enjoyed the diaries since they helped give me more nackground on the story, and they didn't get in the way at all, which is good. The combat is very stacked against you in some cases, but thats great. A challenge in any videogame is a good one. For example, when you run out of ammo, and cash, you need to rely on your sneaking around to get the jump on enemies. Not only is that difficult, but can be very rewarding. It is also noted that when you run out of EVE, you automatically become significantly weaker. This encourages scrounging, exploration to find more hypo or cash, or to sneak around, and try to avoid fights you could previously handle. With hundreds of different ways to play, its a groud breaking game. However, the ending in my opinion was a little fast. I played medium difficultly, and finished the fight in about 3 minutes. This is odd, since I would fight splicers that would take a very long time to kill, due to shortage of supplies and the fact that they would not die after multiple headshots. I feel they could've extended the boss fight slightly more, but thats not all the counts. The Journey is ultimately more fun and exciting than the ending, and it left me a hunger for wanting more. Great game, great mechanics, and would play again.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												I've only finnished this game yesterday and since then I've wanted to write a short review of it. Bioshock is a singleplayer, fps that sells itself on an interesting combat system and unique and complex story. The game is set in the fictional, underwater city of Rapture where a new scientific descovery has caused the citys enhabitents to go mad and murderous and become what are called Splicers. These will be your main enemy for the game along with security bots and Big Daddys as you explore, back-track ( theres allot of that) and then explore some more of the huntingly atmospheric Rapture.Now that i've mentioned the Big Daddys, they serve as optional bosses in the game. By killing them you can ether harvest or rescue the Little Sisters that they gard. If you rescue them then you get a small amout of adam (the currency for upgradeing your abilities) and the "good" ending. If you harvist them then you get lots of adam and the bad ending. But as i said you have to fight the Big Daddy to get these which serves as a nice risk and reward system.The story (no spoilers past the first hour) starts with your un-named silet protagonist's play crashing into Rapture. He is then aided by a man named Atlas who tells your character that in order to escape he must kill the cities founder Andrew Ryan.  Audio tapes reveal bits about the more advanced story. The story grabs you imediately and serve as one of the best parts about Bioshock... until about 2/3s of the way through the game. After an epic plot twist that i wont spoil the game in general becomes a sudden chore.After the twist the game throwes you into a long, boring fetch quest followed by one of the most hideous escort missions that ive ever played (if you hate this escort mission the you probably wont like Bioshock 2). Then there is an easy, anticlimactic boss fight followed by a TERRIBLE 30 second (if you get the good ending like me) cutscene. These missions, story choices acompanied by a huge difficulty spike make the last hour or so awful and boring.The combat system is fun though. You will use a combanation of wepons and plasmids (basicly superpowers) to defeat your enemies. Useing different combos of wepons and plasmids you can find awsome ways to kill people , for example, an electric shock and then a blast from the crossbow is a good one to fight the spider Splicers. You can also hack droids to fight for you, but the hacking mini game is a dredful, anoying mess so unless you use all of your adam upgradeing your hacking abilities.In the end i would definately recomend playing Bioshock as its a great, chilling experience with a cold (if a bit anti-climactic) story, but i would only buy if it was on offer as the game is diffinately without its flaws. Yet despite these flaws im looking farward to playing Bioshock Infinate (i tryed bioshock 2, but didnt enjoy it) to see a new story with some hopefuly improved gameplay.

												"Would you kindly..."BioShock is a game where you take the roll as a man named Jack who has survived a horrible plane crash over the Atlantic ocean and finds himself within the mysterious, derelict, Objectivist city of Rapture. You are contacted by a man calling himself Atlas, claiming that his family is trapped and he needs help to rescue them.But is that all?Questions soon arise, about Rapture and it's people, about the Plasmids that give amazing powers but drive over-users insane. Who is Atlas? He asks you for help, but never is seen nor is his family seen. Why is Andrew Ryan, the once-powerful business magnate and creator of Rapture, holed away instead of trying to aid his city?BioShock is a game that asks questions and deconstructs people, and their actions. With a deep story and beautiful world, it's not a game to be passed up.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												Believe the hype. Irrational Games' incredibly acclaimed horror/action first-person shooter is a remarkable showcase of the games industry's potential for intelligent storytelling and important societal and political relevance. Bioshock is almost as perfect as a game can get, and it is undoubtedly one of the most fun, engaging, and smart games I have played in a long time. In Bioshock, the player is Jack, a generic, middle-aged every-man type character who - after his plane trip takes a detour into the middle of the Atlantic Ocean - finds himself in the underwater city of Rapture, where he must alter his genetic code with plasmids, gather a unique arsenal of weapons, and collect the genetic enhancing drug ADAM in order to survive and escape a crumbling oceanic dystopia. The story is presented as simplistic in the beginning, only to give way to a deeply complex narrative who's subtle roots take subconscious hold very early in the game. Partly through player-exploration (in the finding of citizen recorded audio logs) as well as through linear progression, the player uncovers the dark past of his underwater prison as he finds himself caught between the battles of the city's objectivist/utopia-ist greed monger Andrew Ryan, and a rebel named Atlas who helps the player escape during the game's opening moments. The story works both as a basic narrative, as well as a critique of Utopianism, and the Ayn Rand-founded philosophy of Objectivism. In a moral based storyline, the player witnesses impressive narrative twists and moments that don't disrupt flow, in addition to observing a prediction of an Objectivist society come to life - a world where everyone is only in it for themselves. Not only is the story impressive in and of itself, Bioshock works perfectly as a critique of the ideals of Objectivism/Utopianism, making it one of the most politically and philosophically in-tune games ever. The games accomplishment of deep and rich player immersion is truly remarkable. There's a reason why Rapture has become one of gaming's most recognized locations, and it's resident Big Daddies (and accompanying Little Sisters) some of the industry's most infamous enemies. The games' haunting atmosphere and dark narrative are truly top tier and induct the player with a sense of despair and loneliness, adding to the immersive feel. Surely one of the most captivating experiences I've had with a game.In terms of gameplay, Bioshock hasn't aged a day. Using a unique assortment of weapons (ranging from the famous wrench to more heavy weaponry like the flame-thrower) as well as an array of biological "super power"-type weapons called Plasmids, the player fights their way through armies of Rapture's now-insane citizens called Splicers (driven to their state due to overuse and abuse of the ADAM drug). The gameplay is not only fun and gripping, but also inventive, especially for the time of its release. It's very open-ended, despite the linear design, and the player choice is extremely well-implemented. And the Big Daddy fights are challenging in the best way possible - as well as being equally rewarding. In short, the gameplay in Bioshock is not only superb in its field of First person shooters, but it's some of the best in any game, period. Also worth noting are the graphics. For a game made in 2007 (7 years ago at the time of this review), the game looks great. However, even despite its technical prowess, the art design and level composition is truly incredible. It's one of the many factors that bring Rapture to life, and make it one of the most impressive gaming achievements to date. Bioshock is surely one of the best games ever made. Filled with memorable characters, enemies, and locations, as well as providing an engaging storyline and relevant societal critiques, this is what a game should strive to be. A landmark achievement. 4.5/5

												As a player who decides what games to buy based on the reviews of the certain game, it's my duty to write a complete review about any game i finish, so here is my review:BIOSHOCK:Bioshock is a game where you your character is "trapped" inside the underwater city of Rapture and learns what needs to be done in this zombie-occupied city, most of the times surpassing the limits of the human body, and in the meantime learning what this city was, what it could have been and what it is now and how it got here.Bioshock is a first-person shooter, action, horror game, where you use your guns for damage and your powers, called "Plasmids", as both damage and utilities.Before i procceed with the PROS and CONS i would like to remind anyone who is reading this that these are my personal preferences and may differ by any individual who plays the game.PROS:+This game has really good story.+The graphics are awesome for a 2007 game.+While playing the game, all kinds of emotions will conquer you.+The controlling part feels pretty good.CONS:-Too much amunition, you will reach a point where you dont have space for bullets, same goes with health kits, eve hypos and sometimes even money.-The map is bad, apart from being just a map (only shows the area and the attractions of any kind) it doesnt allow you to place a mark or anything, not even click to see informations about any place.TL;DR This game has his own page in the history of gaming and any serious gamer should at least see a walkthrough of this game, it is probably one of the best ever made.10/10

Posted: November 9, 2015
												The "FPSRPG" kind of games (or as i like to call them, "deus ex" kind of games) can be counted on the fingers of a hand, solely because of the effort that must be put on these kind of titles and the variety that must be offered, but once they are created, and well, they become eternal masterpieces. Bioshock is one of them.The story is finely narrated without pinching the player through boring cutscenes or text walls, but simply by using the "3d actors" that the game offers or the audio logs gathered in an unique 50's nostalgic world filled of details and icons that got bethesda so much in love that they copied that while making Fallout 3 (see pip-boy and the plasmid tutorials).The plot is in background but at the same time will make the player wanting to know more, as you make way through halls of debrises and destruction with your wrench.The gameplay, as in every "Deus ex-y" game, is satisfying and rewarding, made out of many skills and little things to do that can make the player replay the game many more times to see how the character can change in every gameplay. It's good to pick up new skills, it feels good to shoot with your weapons or to thunderstrike with your hands, but if i compare this to his father (System shock 2), the game feels, sure, more dynamic, but ridicolously easy and criminally short.Gameplay: 9/10Story: 8/10Soundtrack 8.5/10Replayability 8.5/10The "must play" for every player that likes RPG-FPS kind of game, and the starting point to whoever wants to begin a genre like that, it's a pity that there aren't as many games as bioshock 1.

Posted: March 28, 2016
												Excellent game! An unforgettable experience. Though, there are a few issues that scream "♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port!" Fortunately, most of them have been fixed by our wonderful PC community.Here are some essential improvements:1) Mouse is wonky in the menu and hacking mini-games - fixed via a mouse fix .bat file posted by Steam user "gudnaimsartaekn"2) No FOV slider - fixed via Flawless Widescreen application3) Physics animations are capped at 30 fps - fixed via Bioshock Physics Unlocker4) There's no built-in ambient occlusion, but if you have an Nvidia gpu, you can enable it in Inspector with the flag: 0x001400005) There's no built-in anti-aliasing. FXAA or SMAA (SweetFX) will do.6) Occassional crashes - running the game in compatibility mode "Windows XP (SP2)" with Admin privileges seems to do the trick. I'm not totally sure.With these improvements, Bioshock runs closer to the way it should have at release, though still not perfect. Crashes can occur randomly or when exiting the game. There are known game-breaking bugs, but I haven't found any, and I've beaten the game 3 times at least. A remaster would be appreciated, but right now this is what we have: a better-than-console version if you tweak it yourself, which can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to do.As far as framerate goes, my i5-4460 and GTX 970 SSC don't break a sweat at 1080p. Rock solid 140 fps with G-Sync.As far as game content goes, everything is gooooood! Without good content, why bother playing at all? :DBioshock is one of the best games ever, as well as its sequel and Infinite. Do yourself a favor and play them all!

												I sometimes wish I could wipe my memory of this game and be able to experience it for the first time again.  I jumped into Bioshock not knowing what to expect other than the fact that there would be Big Daddies littered around the place.  Little did I know I would be thrown into a beautifully desolate underwater city that had been flipped into hell below the sea.  I don't know what I love most about this game. The atmosphere is astonishing, the gameplay is stupidly fun, and the story kept me reeled in like a fish on its final hook.  The whole experience of this game left me wanting so much more from the Rapture/Bioshock universe and I can't express how happy I was when Bioshock 2 came into existence.  If you have ever played Bioshock 2 or Bioshock Infite but have yet to play this game, don't hesitate!  This game still holds up even years after it was released (graphically speaking). Long live Rapture!

And with the sweat of your brow, Rapture can become your city as well.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2013
												BioShock isn't a "shooter" in the conventional sense. Yes there are guns and crazed enemies and wild locales, but this game is so, so much more than your average sci-fi CoD. Without going into too much detail, this game successfully blends story driven gameplay and choices with absolutely stellar level design and first person exploration/combat. BioShock is set in the vivid, stunningly realized underwater world of Rapture, filled to the (literally) bursting point with political intrigue, emotional decisions, stellar (voice) acting and so much more. On the combat side of things, it's geared greatly towards the thinking man, offering a huge plethora of upgrade options, gameplay mechanics and some very unique and interesting abilities. All this would've been much less enjoyable had the AI been neglected, but thankfully the splicers, as they are known, are reasonably intelligent and display some interesting manuvers while fighting.I must cut this short; I could ramble on for a good while about this game. I cannot recommend this highly enough. The sheer sense of "wow, this truly feels like a place that once existed" is off the charts. The combat is addictive. The story is one of the most unique offerings I've seen in videogames, especially the villain. Get this. Especially for one of the frequent bundles with BioShock 2 (also well worth getting, though not quite as stellar) this is just so worth your time.

												It's....It's......BIOSHOCK, ♥♥♥♥♥! The game where you play as Jack, our protagonist! His plane crashed in the mid-atlantic, and you swim to a nearby lighthouse to start your adventure through the world of Rapture, an underwater dystopia, filled with crazed spilcers and insane people. Now, BioShock is a brave game, it knows what it wants to be, and it is. BioShock is an amazing, creative, and scary game, and it has left a huge mark in my soul, for being pants ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ scary. Let me give you the good aspects of BioShock, and show you just how good this game is.Good Aspects of Bioshock-First, we have sound, which is amazing in bioshock, when I first went into the medical pavilion, the crazed wails of the splicers could be heard, the spinning of revolver cylinders from the splicers, the scrapeing of pipes against the hard floor, all done extremly well.-Next we have Rapture itself! Rapture was an underwater city designed by andrew ryan, a rich dude who though the surface was corrupted, so he packed up his bags and set out on his big♥♥♥♥♥cruise ship to sail for the perfect place to build. After years of hard work, he made, Rapture......but.....because of the wonder drug, ADAM, the city has fallen apart and now houses the most crazed, gene spliced losers in the whole world. Leaks are abundent, water is found in most places in rapture. Lights are flickering, showing the dead bodies of the sane rapture population. Rapture is done extremly well.-Next we have GRAPHICS! Graphics are amazing for 2007, good one Irrational, good one. Graphics are done extremly well.-Last but not least, we have the storyline! The story of BioShock is about a....well, find that out yourself......I gave you the rapture story, but there are missing pecies......lots....of missing pecies...(Forgot audio logs, good one Irrational, good one.)Movin on to bad aspects, and I'll tell ya, there aren't many.Bad Aspects of Bioshock-Not optimized for windows 7-8, but it works anyway, and the rare times it won't work, fixes are abundent and easy to find.BioShock is a heart pounder,♥♥♥♥♥♥taking, pants♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ classic, and fun adventure, and should be enjoyed by everyone. My Rating: 9.5 out of 10IncredibleRating System:1/10- Complete Garbage1.5/10= Completly Awful2/10- Awful2.5/10= Completly Terrible3/10- Terrible3.5/10-Almost below average4/10- Below Average4.5/10- Mediocre5/10- Average6/10-Decent6.5/10- OK7/10- Good8/10- Great9/10- Awesome9.5/10 Incredible10/10 PerfectNote: THIS IS FROM THE STORE PAGE, I DID NOT WRITE THISStore Page Info:About the GameBioShock is a shooter unlike any you've ever played, loaded with weapons and tactics never seen. You'll have a complete arsenal at your disposal from simple revolvers to grenade launchers and chemical throwers, but you'll also be forced to genetically modify your DNA to create an even more deadly weapon: you. Injectable plasmids give you super human powers: blast electrical currents into water to electrocute multiple enemies, or freeze them solid and obliterate them with the swing of a wrench. No encounter ever plays out the same, and no two gamers will play the game the same way. Biologically modify your body: send fire storming from your fingertips and unleash a swarm of killer hornets hatched from the veins in your arms. Hack devices and systems, upgrade your weapons and craft new ammo variants. Turn everything into a weapon: the environment, your body, fire and water, and even your worst enemies. Explore an incredible and unique art deco world hidden deep under the ocean.

For example, when you run out of ammo, and cash, you need to rely on your sneaking around to get the jump on enemies. Not only is that difficult, but can be very rewarding. It is also noted that when you run out of EVE, you automatically become significantly weaker. This encourages scrounging, exploration to find more hypo or cash, or to sneak around, and try to avoid fights you could previously handle. With hundreds of different ways to play, its a groud breaking game. However, the ending in my opinion was a little fast. I played medium difficultly, and finished the fight in about 3 minutes. This is odd, since I would fight splicers that would take a very long time to kill, due to shortage of supplies and the fact that they would not die after multiple headshots. I feel they could've extended the boss fight slightly more, but thats not all the counts. The Journey is ultimately more fun and exciting than the ending, and it left me a hunger for wanting more. Great game, great mechanics, and would play again.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2013
												Deep at the bottom of the ocean is the city of Rapture. A city not for Gods or kings, A city for men.Built to be a utopia for mankind's greatest thinkers to prosper.The "world's best and brightest" were granted freedom of will and choice in Rapture, unrestrained by government, religion and similar established institutions. The results were amazing breakthroughs in robotics and genetics.But On December 31, 1958, a massive working-class uprising, led by a man known only as Atlas occurred in upper-class locations in the city, This sparked a civil war in Rapture and marked the beginning of the end.As the player you join the story after it has already concluded, left to wonder the ruins of this once great city, stalked by what's left of the survivors of the war, who due to genetic meddling are not quite human anymore.The game has totally immersive environments that the developers clearly enjoyed creating, accompanied by an original and genuinely interesting story that unfolds before you. With developers being far too willing to bypass story these days for the sake of throw away 'action' moments this game is an exception, Bioshock actually has strong literary references, with clear nods to books such as Logans run and George Orwell's 1984.A very impressive FPS not ruined by the trappings of most modern shooters, no unlimited regenerating health, no unlimited respawns or 10 minute cut scenes. This is an essential game for any self respecting FPS'er.The action starts early and never really slows down. Your own imagination decides how much you get from the conbat system and the enemy AI respodes well to your attack patterns and adjusts accordingly.Would you kindly go and pick up a copy of this game.

												1st person, action, shooter. A whole under water city gone mad, aka Rupture Asylum and genocide on the freaks that live there. Personally I didn't like the story at all. It's pretty much about people with power that wanted everything to be perfect. Then they got bored of it and started doing sick stuff to each other.Plasmids aka the 'super powers' add additional sickness to everything on top, plus the little girls used as harvesters for substance called Adam, that power all the Plasmids. The only humane thing in the game I found, was to save the little girls and help their 'mother' throughout the game, that felt right to do. And apart from her and girls I didn't really find any other positive character. Wont spoil any story, but it wasn't as good as I hoped.For an old game it looked decent, nothing major. Gun play felt very basic though there are many guns available. Enemies were pretty much all humans that were abused by plasmids or experiments, torture, etc., one way or another. Some had interesting abilities in form of vanish / invisibility, walking on walls / ceiling, etc.. AI was challenging, dodging shots, rushing you on, flanking.Plasmid selection was insane and they were fun to use. Looting and hacking was also very enjoyable. After a while game started to drag on, missions and tasks were tedious with all the do this and do that constantly, it felt like I was literally mind controlled in real life. And right after the "Golf scene", I got bored completely.Character design and animations were above average, but nothing good. Visually I guess game was good for it's time, but don't expect much. Voice acting was good and enjoyable. Though I didn't enjoy much of the story, I still recommend this because some people might find it more entertaining than I did. To close this off, for me Bioshock Infinite had far more enjoyable story than this, though they are connected in some way.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												So after a five day binge play of the BioShock franchise, here are my thoughts about the game that started it all. For those who live under rocks, this game started two 'kinda big' controversies. One being the idiotic 'this disk will self destruct' one time instal that the original PC version came with, and the second being that the game was overtly pro-Communism and and anti-Libertarian. Before I get into the right/wrong for this game, let me address both the reasons for uproar. Firstly, video game companies have proven to be nothing but greedy a-holes that we enjoy licking. Born of the mentality that when you buy a game, it's not your property, it still belongs to the game company, we've been gifted with same day DLC, on disk DLC, the war on Game Stop, and still paying $60+ for digital titles. This was one of the first attempts to wrestle ownership of a game away from you and keep it firmly in 2K's hands, and you just pay for the privilege. Kinda funny for a game that seems to extol the virtues of the Communist manifesto that nothing belongs to the individual, to actually do just that! Clever marketing maybe? Anyway, as to the second bit of trouble, the game does go out of it's way to show that the Libertarian idea of free markets and minimal government involvement leads to mass suffering.... until you reach the end of the game. No spoilers, but as the game goes above and beyond in blaming the "Great Chain" for Rapture's destruction, it turns out to be nothing more than a clever plot device. So for all the sore fanny it caused, like most outrage in the media, it was started by people that didn't care enough to investigate the entire title to discover there wasn't any outrage at all. Surprise surprise.RIGHT: BioShock does one thing, and does it incredibly well. This spans for all three titles not just the first. And that one thing is: MOOD. From the second you step into Rapture you are wrapped into a mood of decay and despair so vivid you can almost smell the water damage, and follows you to the very end. BioShock singularly gives this a second helping that the other titles sadly discarded by making the characters look..... surreal. Everything has a 1940's taste and even the characters seem to be odd glassy caricature out of a pulp comic book. Like Half Life, the graphical limitations of the time add a stylized feeling that actually feed into the immersion rather than detracted from it. The second thing these games do, is mess with your emotions. This references to the "controversy" over the games political undertow, but the game rapidly changes pace making you unsure what to think or believe till the very end. Like I say with any game, all the graphics in the world can't save a game that doesn't have a good plot, and BioShock keeps you tied in knots non-stop. The mapping is set up wonderfully for PC FPS players, controls are simple though there is a bit of a learning curve with Weapon/Plasmid combo for the mouse, it will become second nature in no time. You can add on to both your plasmids and weapons, changing effects and visuals letting you customize your combat style and type of play. The voice acting is top notch, again adding to that mood and immersion, the Splicer's vocal taunts are haunting and Big Daddy whale calls will make your flesh crawl. Another incredibly well done feature is the Big Daddy itself. Every area has a certain amount of Big Daddy - Little Sister combos lurching around collecting ADAM, and it is imperative that you defeat them if you want to upgrade your plasmids. But BioShock doesn't just hand them over, oh hell no. You are going to fight and die over and over to get that ADAM, because the Big Daddy's only purpose is to mangle you quickly and without mercy. There are two types: The Bouncer who uses only physical attacks, and Rosie who carries a rivet gun and fires mines. Though toward the end of the game you get use to the combat patterns and have a big enough arsenal that the Big Daddy only becomes moderately dangerous, through the first half of the game these things are ridiculously hard and actually prove a great challenge. WRONG: Some of this I hate to even complain about considering this is a launch title for the franchise, and naturally a proving ground for certain bugs to get fixed and concepts worked out. However, I have a few bones to pick that kept me on the fence for a while. First and foremost, is enemy type. When you first run into the Splicers, they are creepy and horrible, but after the thousandth time you've blown away a male Splicer, their creepiness has long since worn off. Even the Big Daddy loses some of its intimidation by the end of the game and you realize you feel the same playing the final level of Bioshock as you do the final level of COD. It's just a target, remove it, continue on. This game is badly in need of skins for the enemies as well as attack patterns, to give it just a bit more flavor. Secondly is the hacking. Starting the game, I loved to hack things! The pipe and water flow hack was fun and challenging, but by the end of the game I was dreading it and going out of my way to find auto hacks just so I could push ahead. This could have been fixed by adding different hacks for different objects. A hack for vending machines, a hack for security bots, and a hack for vaults. There are too many plasmids that are just, for lack of better terms, worthless. They're great to look at, some have very interesting visuals, but ultimately are just not usable. You will use the Electric plasmid because of it's ability to stun Splicers, Bots, and even the Bid Daddy. You might also take Fire plasmid, but even that loses a lot of its punch toward the end of the game due to the fact that it has little to no effect on Bots, Big Daddy, and even the Splicers just seem to shrug it off. The rest are just gimmicks that work okay or not at all, but wont save you during a fight. Another thing that bothered me was at the end of the game when you dressed in the Big Daddy suit, your hands don't change to give you the feeling that you're in the suit! For a game that goes so far to set a mood, it was kind of a big 'oops' not make this one small visual correct for that scene. And lastly, screw the limited wallet. It's a moronic gimmick to force you spend cash and limit your ability to make pit stops to top off ammunition, rather than just remove that ability all together to make a supply pinch. That aside, BioShock is a fantastic game that has aged well and has plenty of replay value with multiple endings and plenty of hidden items to keep you playing. The story alone is reason enough to grab this title, as it will have direct effect on both of the sequels, adding to their depth and understanding.

FXAA or SMAA (SweetFX) will do.6) Occassional crashes - running the game in compatibility mode "Windows XP (SP2)" with Admin privileges seems to do the trick. I'm not totally sure.With these improvements, Bioshock runs closer to the way it should have at release, though still not perfect. Crashes can occur randomly or when exiting the game. There are known game-breaking bugs, but I haven't found any, and I've beaten the game 3 times at least. A remaster would be appreciated, but right now this is what we have: a better-than-console version if you tweak it yourself, which can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to do.As far as framerate goes, my i5-4460 and GTX 970 SSC don't break a sweat at 1080p. 												**** DONT LET THE HOURS FOOL YOU, IVE COMPLETED THIS GAME 5+ TIMES ON ALL DIFFICULTIES ON CONSOLE, THE GAME JUST DOESNT WANNA RUN ON WINDOWS 10****** WILL CONTAIN SLIGHT SPOILERS **9 Years ago, we got Gears of War, Halo 3 and Call of Duty Modern Warfare. It was already a good year for gaming, but then you added Bioshock to the list. A game series that is still my favourite ever, and specifically a game that has been my favourite game of all time for a very very long time. I was 12 or 13 when this game came out. I was more in to the likes of Call of Duty or Gears, but my dad bought me this game for my birthday. I read up a little bit about the game before I started playing and wasnt happy to see it was a single player game with horror aspects.(Im a bit of a baby when it comes to horror games)Regardless, I put the disc in and hit play. This was the moment where a whole new world was opened up to me, Rapture,  Andrew Ryan, Atlas, Splicers and the whole messed up city under the sea. Why are these people so angry? Why do these little girls have glowing eyes? Why am I here?These were questions I had about 30 minutes in to the game.The story of rapture is so unique, and in depth that you wont learn a lot of the current history or lore while playing this game. You need to play Boshock 2 and Infinites DLC to figure out more (I also recommend the book Rapture: Bioshock by John Shirley, this is where youll learn the most about the history of the city under the sea and the people who made it to what it is now).LISTEN TO ALL THE RECORDING TAPES, THIS IS WHERE YOU LEARN SO MUCH ABOUT THE GAMES STORYThe game falls short for a lot of people when it comes to gameplay, and I find that arguable considering the game did come out 9 years ago. But I also think it is a fair thing to consider for new buyers or people looking to get in to the franchise. The combat is dull and simplistic in its own.But I think the fact that there are gun upgrades, plasmids (Plasmids give you different powers to use) and a variety of different ways to go around things when facing enemies, is enough to keep the game exciting when it comes to its fights.The atmosphre and visuals of this game are some of the best in gaming, ever. Bioshock has something of a trick to just make you feel as if you are there, in the world of Rapture. From gardens with poisonious plants, to freezing rooms where you have to melt walls of ice to progress, this game never failsw to make your FEEL your enviroment. Something a lot of games fall short on.The truth is...I cant find anything wrong with this game, its perfect. This game and this series are so special and incredible that I cant give it anything less than a 10/10. This world will amaze you. It will scare you. It will surprise you and it will sadden you. If you havent played this game of any in the series, please, I beg you, play them. This game is an absolute master piece and the other games fall from the same tree. Buy this game, play it, immerse yourself. I promise you 100%, you will not regret it.

												========================Plot Twist Simulator 2007========================Atmosphere: Fantastic!Graphics: Considered that this is a game from 2007, the graphics are extremely good!Story: The story of the city is the best part about this game, I like the idea of having audio diaries spreaded around the city;(Spoiler!)I have no problem with the good ending, but the two other endings doesn't really make sense for me. The choices that I've made through out the game don't really correlate to those two ending scenes, there is no direct or logical relationship between harvesting little sisters and devouring the surface world. "But in the end even Rapture was not enough for you..." Seriously I just want to get the ♥♥♥♥ out of this underwater graveyard!Sound: Great in general, the ambient sounds are nicely done; but the dialogues from random splicers are a bit repetitive (Ive heard the "Jesus loves me yes I know" song for like seven times through out the game)Music: Fantastic! They have put a lot of effort into the soundtrack. I love Sander Cohen's masterpiece :DGameplay: The first half of the game is pretty fun, I enjoyed it very much. However during the mid-late game, things get a bit dull without new weapons and new plasmids but only upgrades. Good thing is, the story became more intense during this part of the game so that the game is still fun. The last part of the game gets interesting again because of the new mission type. The boss fight is a bit too easy,you just have to run around in circles, and then the fight is more or less the same as fighting 3 bouncers with bad range attacks, one after another.Overall: 8/10A wonderful game! One of my favourites!Although its gameplay is not as good as Bioshock 2, the mystery and atmosphere have made this game one of the best fps ever.Other notes: Easy mode is extremely easy, play on this setting only if you are new to video games; Medium mode is also easy, play on this setting if you are new to FPS games; Hard mode should be good for most players. On hard mode your health will drain very fast against stronger enemies, so you will have to explore the entire map for resources. Install Mods if you want a "true" hard mode.

												It's....It's......BIOSHOCK, ♥♥♥♥♥! The game where you play as Jack, our protagonist! His plane crashed in the mid-atlantic, and you swim to a nearby lighthouse to start your adventure through the world of Rapture, an underwater dystopia, filled with crazed spilcers and insane people. Now, BioShock is a brave game, it knows what it wants to be, and it is. BioShock is an amazing, creative, and scary game, and it has left a huge mark in my soul, for being pants ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ scary. Let me give you the good aspects of BioShock, and show you just how good this game is.Good Aspects of Bioshock-First, we have sound, which is amazing in bioshock, when I first went into the medical pavilion, the crazed wails of the splicers could be heard, the spinning of revolver cylinders from the splicers, the scrapeing of pipes against the hard floor, all done extremly well.-Next we have Rapture itself! Rapture was an underwater city designed by andrew ryan, a rich dude who though the surface was corrupted, so he packed up his bags and set out on his big♥♥♥♥♥cruise ship to sail for the perfect place to build. After years of hard work, he made, Rapture......but.....because of the wonder drug, ADAM, the city has fallen apart and now houses the most crazed, gene spliced losers in the whole world. Leaks are abundent, water is found in most places in rapture. Lights are flickering, showing the dead bodies of the sane rapture population. Rapture is done extremly well.-Next we have GRAPHICS! Graphics are amazing for 2007, good one Irrational, good one. Graphics are done extremly well.-Last but not least, we have the storyline! The story of BioShock is about a....well, find that out yourself......I gave you the rapture story, but there are missing pecies......lots....of missing pecies...(Forgot audio logs, good one Irrational, good one.)Movin on to bad aspects, and I'll tell ya, there aren't many.Bad Aspects of Bioshock-Not optimized for windows 7-8, but it works anyway, and the rare times it won't work, fixes are abundent and easy to find.BioShock is a heart pounder,♥♥♥♥♥♥taking, pants♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ classic, and fun adventure, and should be enjoyed by everyone. My Rating: 9.5 out of 10IncredibleRating System:1/10- Complete Garbage1.5/10= Completly Awful2/10- Awful2.5/10= Completly Terrible3/10- Terrible3.5/10-Almost below average4/10- Below Average4.5/10- Mediocre5/10- Average6/10-Decent6.5/10- OK7/10- Good8/10- Great9/10- Awesome9.5/10 Incredible10/10 PerfectNote: THIS IS FROM THE STORE PAGE, I DID NOT WRITE THISStore Page Info:About the GameBioShock is a shooter unlike any you've ever played, loaded with weapons and tactics never seen. You'll have a complete arsenal at your disposal from simple revolvers to grenade launchers and chemical throwers, but you'll also be forced to genetically modify your DNA to create an even more deadly weapon: you. Injectable plasmids give you super human powers: blast electrical currents into water to electrocute multiple enemies, or freeze them solid and obliterate them with the swing of a wrench. No encounter ever plays out the same, and no two gamers will play the game the same way. Biologically modify your body: send fire storming from your fingertips and unleash a swarm of killer hornets hatched from the veins in your arms. Hack devices and systems, upgrade your weapons and craft new ammo variants. Turn everything into a weapon: the environment, your body, fire and water, and even your worst enemies. Explore an incredible and unique art deco world hidden deep under the ocean.

												Loved this game. It may be a few years old, but I couldn't tell from the graphics, which were still stellar. The story is extremely well done and engaging throughout- you will be searching for every voxophone and going down every side corridor to learn more. Gameplay was also very fun- I played on Normal difficulty, which was challenging enough that I was never bored, while not being hard enough that I was frustrated. There weren't too many weapons to choose from (and to be honest some just didn't seem that effective compared to the standard Wrench) but I never found myself bored or distracted by that fact. Same with the Plasmids (basically, magic spells)- I almost always used the standard Electric Shock, but the others were still interesting and the gameplay forced you to use some of the other Plasmids in order to unlock secret areas or find hidden voxophones which advanced the story. In sum, I would give this game an 8/10, with a recommendation for people who want an engaging story to go with their gameplay.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												This is a game worthy of praise. Bioshock is an example of a game that does not get repetitive in story. The setting itself is quite original from most shooters to start with. This game also gives you a diverse range of ways to kill opponents and a lot of back story, which is not common for most videogames. The fighting is fairly simple, with a flair for dramatic deaths and a way to make quick allies. The fighting is very satisfying and new players can catch on quickly. The story is so well written and dialouged with excellent voice actors that you are drawn into it. The silent protagonist makes you sympathize with his situation from the very start. The plot twist could not have also been better delivered. The Plasmids also make fighting enemies an extremely creative process, I dare say an art form. No two people may choose the exact same plasmids as another person, making this game very fluid in its ability to offer many ways to combat enemies in the game, not just limited to run and gun. Stealth is also an important component in this game when you are low on ammo or are surrounded by numerous enemies and big daddies, often outting you at a disadvantage. The layout of the levels are also very condusive to the atmosphere and the the music score was flawless. The last thing is that though this game may not be known as a horror title, it definitly has its moments that frighten you. This game is so well made that I would dare recomend it even to people who only like playing sports games. This game whould be labled in my opinion the best well rounded, because of all its attributes and pluses. I can't even really think of anything bad or negative to say, though then again, I never really say anything bad because I always look for what is best in a game. This game has my full confidence. If you are planning to buy, you should have full confidence that this game will give you the best time for your money. ever.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												A steam punk horror FPS that will leave your jimmies quite rustled. Bioshock is the first game introduced into what would later become one of the best non-conforming FPS games to date. Filled with many twists and turns that will surely leave you scratching your head and really bringing the undersea world of Rapture to life. Bioshock is an intriguing title that tries, and sometimes fail, to spook you at every turn. The rusted and dilapidated environment accompanied with the pitter-patter of water hitting the  iron-clad walls and floor will bring the city of Rapture to life. An exhilarating story with many M. Night Shyamalan twists that really make the player sit down and think about what has happened through their experience in Rapture. A game that definitely has a story with a punch, but with some lacking basic fundamentals you'd expect to find in a FPS. Unfortunately, Bioshock isn't the best FPS for a number of reasons including difficulty when using spray (it's better to use guns as if they were semi-automatic for accuracy), a lot of the enemies move in strange ways that will cause them to complete dodge your shots if they're a certain distance from you (makes it very difficult unless you're aiming low when they are meleeing), and worst of all your only melee weapon is garbage even with all of the upgrades equipped. This makes medium to long range fights the best for you but there's constantly something running at you in your face. The FPS mechanics do take some getting used to and are pretty interesting, the fact that you don't zoom with right mouse button but with Z is definitely something most FPS don't do. Over the years the graphics have held up very well too and at the time of it's release it was hailed for it's intense computer requirements (thankfully much easier to acquire now). Bioshock is a title that deserves respect and while it's not fundamentally the best game the story is worth at least one trip though.☆★★★★ Overall ☆★★★★ Gameplay ★★★★★ Story ☆★★★★ Graphics ☆★★★★ Sounds ☆★★★★ Oddity ☆☆★★★ Length

content:
Posted: May 24, 2014
												Quite possibly my favourite game of all time.BioShock puts you in the shoes of a man named Jack, his plane crashing in the middle of the ocean.  With nowhere to go, he spots a lighthouse.  Going inside, he takes a Bathysphere into the underwater world of Rapture, a city where the brightest sparks of society have gathered.  Quite quickly you begin to notice that, while looking pretty on the outside, the city isn't what it seems to be; non-existent morals and a civil war have turned this city into an abandoned mess, its inhabitants becoming addicts and constantly searching for the wonder drug ADAM.  Having to defend yourself with weapons made by man and superpowers developed by the citizens (fueled by EVE) you'll have to protect yourself as everyone comes after you.  The rest of the plot is more enjoyable to experience yourself so I'll just stop here.This game is simply amazing.  The graphics still look great to me after SEVEN YEARS, Rapture itself still being nice to look at.  The atmosphere is fantastic and, for once, I actually gave a♥♥♥♥♥♥about the collectible items; the audio diaries you find are interesting and enjoyable to listen to, each one being a treat.  Combat is cool, the enemies are fun to fight, the characters are all extremely interesting, everything is a treat.  What the best feature was for me however was definitely the story of Rapture itself; a city gone mad, its leaders going crazy for power, a war tearing it apart, it's truly phenomenal.One can only ask how a game can be made as a spiritual successor yet still define itself in its own way.  Then you get BioShock and you understand.

												None FPS fans read on!I am not, by any stretch of the imagination, a fan of FPS games.  They bore me to death in all honesty; so it was with some trepidation I gave Bioshock a go, having picked up all three games for a fiver in the Steam summer sale (can't go wrong for five quid, surely, I thought).I am pleased to say that Bioshock is a fantastic game.  Rapture is remarkable.  The whole game has a very unique feel to it, and best of all, once you get into it, you have the option of how to play - you don't have to barrel through the corridors all guns blazing if you don't want to.  Instead I chose to creep around, hurling bees at the Splicers which was frankly as amusing the hundredth time to me as it was the first.The story is very good, boosted significantly by the environment, which makes you want more.  Having just finished the vastly inferior Bioshock Infinite I can in all honesty say that Bioshock is a one of a kind game; from stepping through those doors for the first time to the brief but satisfying (or not so much depending on your choices thoughout the game) ending, this is the kind of game that comes along once every so often and won't be repeated.Thumbs up, would shoot bees from hands again

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I've been taking the time to think about BioShock. On one hand, there is the "Cult of Shock 2" that retain a savage disdain for BioShock because of it's extremely obvious narrative and gameplay similarities to System Shock 2. On the other hand, there are gamers that reasonably acknowledge that BioShock's elements are derivitive of System Shock 2 and claim that the elements were streamlined for a newer generation. I know BioShock fans that have given copious amounts of evidence and suggestions to back this up, and I don't necessarily agree or disagree with that. That is a matter of prefrence. When someone takes the time to deconstruct and analyze System Shock 2, you'll find that it is a deeply and intracately woven role-playing experience where the player needed to become familliar with varying amounts of important elements to create their characters, specialize in specific statistics, and really just to experience the game once as an introduction to it all and play through a second time to experience the game properly. Many critics praised these very aspects that made System Shock 2 one of the greatest games ever created and the sales were miserable.When someone takes the time to deconstruct and analyze BioShock, you'll find a game that has that overall feeling of intracacy laced within the narrative with more understandable gameplay elements that were designed, in principle, to appeal to a large audience. There are elements that can be considered RPG elements and the game had the basis of it's core gameplay display itself as a suspense game in a few areas and a balls-to-the-wall action FPS in most others. The gaming community—especially the parts of it that sided with the "Cult of Shock 2"—was split and BioShock became 2K Games' most profitable franchise at that time.When you take a look at the bigger picture, System Shock 2 and BioShock are two completely different games in principle and two very similar games in execution. When you get down to it, the "dumbing down" of System Shock 2's qualities was enforced, not by a corporate publisher or a greedy fat man in a black suit, but by the developers' own desire to make their baby, System Shock 2, more understandable. If you take the time to search up some interviews and stuff for System Shock 2 featuring Ken Levine and Looking Glass Studios (which is now 2K Games), you can tell that System Shock 2 was their pride and joy, and it must have been devastating when it became ignored by the central PC community. To that extent, I can understand more reasonably (and even forgive) a few of my previous issues with this title. I used to have a psychotic hatred for this game based on System Shock 2, and my previous review that I wrote for this game was an over-glorified comparison to System Shock 2. I'm not going to make the same mistake here in this rewrite, as I've come to the conclusion that to judge BioShock by System Shock 2 would be very unfair, as I think any fan of System Shock 2 would probably agree when I say that System Shock 2 is the better of the two titles.BioShock, on its own, is an okay game. I don't think it's the genre-defining work of art that the gaming industry seems to think it is, but I don't think that it's the water-logged, hollowed out corpse of SS2 that the "Cult of Shock 2" thinks it is. It does a few things right and it does a lot of things wrong, and in the very end it's up to the fans of System Shock 2 to decide whether or not they want to take BioShock as its own experience. As one of the BIGGEST fans of SS2 out there, I'm reviewing this game from that perspective.The gameplay elements found in BioShock all consist of unorthodox forms of first-person shooting and RPG elements without numbers. This game borrows implicitly from SS2's horror elements by including a few scenes that really do peak the player's intrest, but the attempts at horror are completely futile. The game can't be called a survival game because it isn't one, and resource management is way too easy, even on difficulty settings over Normal. These sections are far and few between as most of the game plays as a balls-to-the-wall action shooter. However, these sections are mediated by fluent pace changes every so often. Whereas other games from 2007 would often have you just shooting at everything coming by, this game takes a slower, more methodical approach to let you appreciate the vibe of what you're doing and really take in the enviorment as well as the NPCs populating it. The NPCs are hopeless drug addicts; you're a killer, and you feel like one...except when you deal with Big Daddies and Little Sisters.Despite everything else wrong with the game, *BIG DADDIES ARE FRIGGING AWESOME*, and anyone who tells you otherwise hasn't played this game. The Little Sisters, on the other hand, are the *lowest* rung on the morality ladder. Essentailly, the Little Sisters are little girls that you can either choose to save or harvest for Adam. You get more Adam for harvesting them and less for saving them. If you save all of them, you get the good ending, and if you harvest just ONE of them, you get the bad ending. Without spoiling anything, they both mean absolutely nothing and you can just watch them on YouTube. Without any character development, killing or saving the Little Girls becomes based on the reward. Would you rather have less Adam or more Adam? Exactly.The gunplay is very unsatisfying. I'm going to be a hypocrite for a few characters and say that SS2 also had unsatisfying gunplay, but you almost never used your gun because ammo was low and most of the gunplay was backed up by the horror elements of the game. Here, the weak sounding weapons and overexaggerated reactions result in gunplay that feels like a chore to sort through. There are moments when it's satisfying to take down a Big Daddy, but that's satisfaction from the challenge and not the actual gunplay.Besides shooting, BioShock includes two performance enhancing bodily modifications called "Plasmids" and "Gene Tonics". Plasmids are essentially powers you recieve from completing missions (and you can always buy them at the vending machine). Gene Tonics are the RPG Elements without numbers I was writing about earlier. They are pretty much character enhancements that set up your character to adopt certain play styles. For example, you can put together an invisibility tonic and a melee damage tonic to take on the role of a stealth assassin. For the game's other shortcomings, that's pretty cool.The game also features hacking mini-games in the form of circuit-based puzzles. You connect a set of pipes so water can successfully travel from one end of the circuit to another. While doing this, the game pauses and you always will have the right pieces at the right time, killing tension. If they really wanted to include some much needed tension, then they could have accelerated the current of the water whenever a piece was misplaced, or they could have provided a certain amount of each directional pipe, causing some inevitable ambiguation as to where to construct a direct path. They also could have made it so there was a tangible loss with each failure. There is no tangible loss when dying. There are Vita Chambers, which are essentially respawn points that make the game much easier than it already is, and then there's just going back to the main menu if you decide to shut it off.Like I said, I don't hate BioShock, nor do I carry the attitude I once had towards it like the "Cult of Shock 2". I don't think it's a revolutionary work of art either. I think it's okay. Not terrible, but not great. It's great in some areas and abhorrent in others, and what's there good is great and what's bad is horrible.3/5 - Okay. Worth a rental or a purchase (only if the price goes down).

content:
Posted: August 8, 2013
												As a game alone, could I recommend Bioshock?  The gunplay is floaty and 'off'.  It's difficult to explain, but the guns in Bioshock don't give as much feedback and aren't as satisfying as guns in games today.  Even comparing it to other games around the time of its release in 2007 doesn't do it much good.  Okay, so boo hoo, the "Run 'n' Gun" strategy isn't going to work in this game.  However, another mechanic balances this out - the use of plasmids.  These genetically granted powers allow you to stun, burn, and freeze enemies, allowing for a wide variety of strategies and traps. Zapping an enemy with lightning sure does make it a lot easier to get close enough to force-feed him a belt of ammo.Exploration is very rewarding in this game.  So much so, that if you're like me, you'll end up being full of loot half the time.  While I thought that they could scale back on how much loot was lying around the ravenged city of Rapture, I really liked the map you're given.  It highlighted areas you had already explored, which meant you wouldn't spend ten minutes backtracking trying to find that one door you *thought* was where you were supposed to go, so you skipped it to keep looking for loot, but it turns out you actually went the right way and so now you need to find it again to explore the hallway and two rooms behind it.I also really liked how fights with the Big Daddies worked.  They weren't agressive unless you attacked them, meaning you could hold off killing them until you were prepared; however, even when fully prepared, Big Daddies have a couple different attacks, making them formidable opponents.Based on gameplay alone, Bioshock is fun, but it hasn't exactly aged gracefully.  Don't interpret that to mean I don't like the game though.  Both the story and characters are very engaging.  It's the small things, like the interactions between the Big Daddies and their Little Sisters and "idle dialouge" (randomly chosen lines spoken by enemies that have little to no bearing on the story/plot and only serve to heighten atmosphere), that really made me enjoy this game.Having just competed the entire game a second time, I plan on going back for at least a third.

												Seeing the ridiculous amounts of hype, i could not wait to play Bioshock.With its apparently mesmerising storyline and beautiful…well, everything. It seemed like it would be the perfect game for me...The storyline, i must say is truly wonderful, an innovative idea that's extremely well thought out and executed. This is accompanied by the also stunning visuals and environment style which are perfect for achieving the grungy, dystopian and eerie style that’s so synonymous with the series.Unfortunately, this did not make me impressed enough with the game enough to actually fall in love with it, or even like it slightly more than the average RPG. The gameplay style is very original, making it more of a ‘real life gun holding simulator’ than an FPS. This was highly annoying at times unfortunately.  Although this style has it’s charms, its slightly more irritating than ‘fun’.  Plasmids are pretty damn awesome but after using them on your 5000th bot, they get very boring. Which brings me on to my next point… It’s so damn repetitive. With the occasional plot point being the only thing that’s keeping you going, you battle through hordes of splicers again and again… and again…Basically, the longer you play, the more bored you get. With one or two twists in the story line that re-activate your interest in the game occasionally, I can say… I was vey disappointed in the game.It’s a beautifully made, artistic… boring game. Not saying it's bad, but its just quite boring at times. 60/100BTW This is a good game, but during the middle of it? It's pretty damn boring.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
BioShock™ as well as the Bioshock series will always remain as one of the best FPS game. The storyline is very thought-provoking with breathtaking twist and turns, together with many riddles throughout the game, from collecting and listening to diaries, to solving puzzels in order to advance through the game. It will surely bring you an awesome experience (and touching as well...). The AI are well designed, they are not some random guys just standing there waiting to be killed. To be honest, sometimes the Splicers, specially Big Daddies really annoyed me because it took me a while in order to defeat just only one guy (but still, i think that's what made BioShock even better). When i see the graphics in game, i couldn't belive this game was released in 2007. The landscape in Rapture is so realistic, the lights, the water, the smoke, the blood, all contributed to the "Fallen Rapture" scenery perfectly. The gameplay is great too, at first when i was entering Rapture as Jack, i knew i had to play "sneaky-beaky like." But as i advanced throughout the game, i realized that i can both stealth and play "Rambo" at the sametime. And believe me, it feels really awesome when you've killed a Leadhead Splicer (LoL). The sound also made big contributions to the game as well, this is the first game that allows me to hear the enemies singing, muttering, or just talking about weird-random things, it made me feel creepy and funny at the same time.I don think that this game has any cons, it's just too perfect, and here are my ratings:Storyline: 10/10Graphics: 9.5/10Gameplay: 9/10Sound: 9.5/10"And now, would you kindly buy and play this game without hesitation?"

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												This is honestly one of my favorite games of all time, due to it's incredible story, atmosphere, and social commentary. The graphics are still stunning for this day and age, but you shouldn't even think of playing this game for graphics. Do that with Bioshock Infinite. This game, though, is raw and horrific. It is relentless and will have you questioning your morals while playing it. While not open world, Bioshock has an incredibly captivating setting of Rapture, an underwater city ravaged by political corruptness. The special "abilities" of freezing, electrocuting, and tormenting people feels sadistically satisfying, and gunplay is comfortable for even the most experienced FPS players. The atmosphere never lets up, and you will come across things you can't believe - characters with sickening goals and disturbing monologues. One early game, a doctor, is incredibly terrifying. But, enough rambling - I can't stress enough that you need to sit down with this game and appreciate what a gem it is in the gaming industry.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												A truly stunning game that is utterly amazing and that I would highly recommend buying. It is a very fun fps that you can either breeze through or challenge yourself. It also has a beautiful, beautiful story, this is a game where you go out of your way to find out as much of the story line you just can. The combat is very fun and gives a new play style to fps and is a very unique game which is just wonderfully done.A few thingsIf you are weak at horror games this might be a little scary and I myself got a bit a scared on some parts. While it may be creepy I do not believe it to be a true horror game rather jut creepy and gory.It has recordings on parts and I would recommend finding as many of those as you can even if you it isn’t necessary it just adds to the games feel and gives a more fun experience. The game is very different from the average shooter and the combat is very enjoyable with many different powers and plasmids (awesome powers that you shoot out from your hand) you get to freeze, burn, sting (yes sting with bees), electrocute and blow up your foes.The story is very, very good and has a pretty well done ending that was satisfying and I myself intend to play it again and try to find a few of the recordings I missed.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												The atmosphere in Bioshock is one of the most memorable parts for me when I first played this game. Rapture is one of the most dramatic and beautiful cities created in a game, that lets you get fully immersed in its lore and enviroments. From the frightening opening, and through the whole harrowing of the underwater city the game gives you something new every step of the way. The story is the other greatest element, for it is full of memorable characters and unpredictable plot twists. I was able to perfectly run the game on my PC, with only two ocasions of crashes, one being my own fault (do not throw a gas cylinder at the tennis ball machine.) It is a great FPS that everyone interested in the genre should try.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I'll never forget how incredible the first 30 minutes of game play was to me when i first got this. It had been out for a few months by this point and incredibly i had heard nothing of the game other than a vague report from a friend it might be alright (months before it's release). The events of those first thirty minutes (trying not to give anything away here) quite literally had me sitting on the edge of my seat mouth open wide. It wasn't just the story, it was the immersion effect it had on me. Had a console version back then and played it through a few times.Now owing a pc version i decided to have another wander through Rapture. Boy am i glad i did! Lots of things i remembered, plenty i forgot. But what really had me was how well it has stood up to the test of time. I just plain enjoy everything about this game. Graphics and animations are beautiful with creative level design coupled with dynamic lighting that really gives the sensation of being on the bottom of the ocean, even if it is a little dated. Yes there is a bit of backward and forward grinding to be done mission wise, but the story/tapes you uncover along the way i feel are worth it and help the overall story. All in all Bioshock is a classic and a fantastic 25-35 hour adventure. My Specs: i7 4770          16GB Ram                  GTX770 OC (4GB VRAM)Thanks for reading! :)

												I've always been more of an RPG gal, and avoided FPS games, but this game is a good mix of both. It kept me on the edge of my seat, as they say. In fact, there were quite a few times while playing where I was terrified, skulking around slowly, hearing the voices of enemies, yet unable to see them. This game has stunning visuals, and the audio, well, you have to keep it turned up! I love the dystopian art plastered all over the walls as well! Although the ending was a bit sudden, I loved ithe game! Now, I just have to decide whether to play Bioshock 2 now or Bioshock Infinite!
